They wish to refer legislation to Taghut, while they were commanded to reject him; and Satan wishes to lead them far astray. And when it is said to them, "Come to what Allah has revealed and to the Messenger," you see the hypocrites turning away from you in aversion." (an-Nisa'/4: 60-61)
text.50: Then Allah poses a question regarding the reasons that make the hypocrites behave in such a way. Is it because there is indeed a disease in their hearts, so they are always doubtful of any decision that harms them, even though evidence and arguments strengthen that decision? Or is it that they are fundamentally doubtful about the apostleship and prophethood of Muhammad (peace be upon him)? Or are they worried that Allah and His Messenger will act unjustly towards them? That is their character, behavior, and traits. The traits of people who have gone astray, unwilling to accept the truth if it will harm them. Those are the traits of the disbelievers who have gone astray. They are the zalim (wrongdoers) who like to harm others and are also zalim to themselves.
text.51: Those who truly believe, when invited to accept Allah and His Messenger as arbiters, submit and obediently accept the decision, whether the decision benefits or harms them. They are convinced with all their heart, without the slightest doubt, that the decision is the correct one, because it is the decision of Allah and His Messenger. Of course, whose decision is more worthy of acceptance and belief in its truth and justice than the decision of Allah and His Messenger? Such are the characteristics of those who truly believe in Allah and His Messenger and are fully convinced that Allah is the Most Truthful and Most Just.
text.52: Whoever obeys all of Allah's commands and avoids all His prohibitions, believing that carrying out Allah's commands will lead to happiness in this world and the Hereafter, and that abandoning all His prohibitions will keep them away from danger and disaster in this world and the Hereafter, and who always fears Him (taqwa), and does good to fellow human beings, then they are among those who attain Divine pleasure and are free from all His torment in the Hereafter.
text.53:
In this verse, Allah again explains the behavior of the hypocrites, namely that they easily utter grand promises reinforced with oaths, but they never fulfill them. They swear by the name of Allah that if they are asked to participate in war alongside the believers, they will certainly participate and will not refuse, regardless of their circumstances and situation, and without considering what will happen in the war, as if they are truly convinced that the command to fight is for the common good and to uphold the religion of Allah. But Allah knows what is hidden in their hearts, that if they are truly invited to fight against the enemy, they will seek excuses and reasons so that they do not participate and just stay in Medina. Therefore, Allah commands the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) to forbid them from swearing, because such an oath carries a heavy risk. They do not need to swear because Allah already knows that their obedience and compliance are only lip service and do not arise from a pure conscience. In line with this verse, Allah says:

"They will swear to you so that you may accept them. But even if you accept them, Allah will never be pleased with the defiantly disobedient people." (at-Taubah/9: 96)

And His saying:

"And they swear by Allah that they are truly of you, while they are not of you; rather, they are a people who are afraid." (at-Taubah/9: 56)

Therefore, Allah reminds them of the false oaths they utter and threatens to inflict a fitting recompense for their evil deeds, and explains that He knows all their behavior and their evil intentions, as well as the deceptions they orchestrate to deceive the Muslims.
text.54: Then Allah commanded Prophet Muhammad again to tell them to obey Allah and His Messenger sincerely. Do not always pretend to believe, but their actions and behavior contradict the words they utter. This is as a final warning to them. If they still turn away from the truth and do things that harm the struggle of the Muslims, then tell them that the sin of their actions will be borne on their own shoulders and will not harm the Prophet and the Muslims in the slightest. They will receive Allah's wrath and His punishment. If they truly obey and come out of error by accepting the guidance of Allah and His Messenger, then surely they will be among the fortunate ones. The Messenger's duty is only to convey guidance and advice. Accepting or rejecting is each individual's decision, beyond the Messenger's responsibility.
text.55:
Rabi' bin Anas once said regarding this verse, "The Prophet Muhammad saw was in Mecca for ten years calling the disbelievers of Mecca to the religion of monotheism, worshipping Allah without associating partners with Him, while the believers were always in fear and anxiety. They had not yet been commanded to fight. Then they were commanded to migrate to Medina. After that command was carried out, the command to fight was revealed. They were always in fear and anxiety, always carrying weapons morning and evening, and they remained steadfast and patient. Then a companion came to the Prophet and said, "O Messenger of Allah, must we remain in this anxiety and vigilance forever? When will the time come when we can feel safe and free from carrying weapons?" So the Messenger of Allah saw replied, "You will not have to wait long for that situation. The time will soon come when a person can sit in a large gathering where there is not a single weapon in that gathering." Then this verse was revealed.

Allah promises those who believe and do righteous deeds that He will make them rulers on earth. He will make their religion a firm and strong religion, and He will grant them the blessings of security and prosperity. That is Allah's promise, and that promise is certain to be fulfilled because it is impossible for Allah to break His promise as long as they hold fast to His commands and teachings. Indeed, that promise has been fulfilled with the successive victories achieved by the Muslims during the time of the Prophet saw and during the time of the Khulafa'urrasyidin and afterwards. During the time of the Prophet Muhammad, the Muslims were able to conquer the city of Mecca, Khaibar, Bahrain, and the entire Arabian Peninsula.

After the Prophet saw passed away and the government was controlled by the companions (Khulafaurrasyidin), they always followed the footsteps of the Messenger of Allah saw in all matters. Thus, their power expanded to the east, west, north, and south, and the religion of Islam spread rapidly, so that it was embraced by the people of the countries that were successfully conquered without coercion or threats. They truly enjoyed security and prosperity. The Islamic government truly became strong, respected by friends and foes.

Allah has reminded the Muslims who have successfully achieved victory, security, and prosperity with His word:

And remember when you (Muhajirin) were few and oppressed in the land (of Mecca), fearing that people would abduct you, but He sheltered you, strengthened you with His victory, and provided you with good things so that you might be grateful. (al-Anfal/8: 26)

Thus, the Muslims became strong and respected, enjoying security and prosperity during the time of the Caliphs Abu Bakar, Umar, Usman, until a great conflict arose among the Muslims during the reign of Ali bin Abi thalib, resulting in civil war among themselves, even though war among Muslims is very contrary to the word of Allah:

And hold firmly to the rope of Allah all together and do not become divided. And remember the favor of Allah upon you - when you were enemies and He brought your hearts together and you became, by His favor, brothers. (Ali 'Imran/3: 103)

And His word:

And do not be like those who separated and differed after clear proofs had come to them. And those will have a great punishment. (Ali 'Imran/3: 105)

Since then, there have been ups and downs in Islamic governance. At one time they were victorious and glorious, and at another time they were weak and helpless, even becoming prey for other people, according to their circumstances and conditions in practicing the teachings of Islam, obeying the commands of Allah and His Messenger, upholding justice and truth, and maintaining the unity of the ummah so that it would not be divided.
text.56: In this verse, Allah accompanies the promise of achieving victory with the command to establish prayer (salat), pay zakat, and obey Allah and His Messenger. This is the first condition for achieving victory and maintaining it. Sometimes achieving something is not so difficult, but preserving the continuity of what has been achieved is more difficult than achieving it. Therefore, Muslims must strengthen themselves and cultivate their defenses with these three very powerful weapons: first, strengthening the inner self by always connecting with the Almighty. Second, zakat, which cleanses oneself from the traits of stinginess and miserliness, so that when the time comes, one will not hesitate to sacrifice wealth, energy, and even life. Third, obedience and submission to Allah and His Messenger, where all actions are aligned with His teachings, and if there are differences of opinion, they should be referred back to the law of Allah and His Messenger. This is what becomes the guideline for all movements and steps. By fulfilling these three conditions, the strength of the ummah and its resilience against all threatening dangers can be built, and the success that has been achieved can be maintained and preserved.
text.57: In this verse, Allah affirms to the Prophet Muhammad that the disbelievers will not be able to escape Allah's punishment if Allah wills their destruction or the collapse of their power. Therefore, do not overestimate their strength as long as the Muslims maintain their condition with the three conditions mentioned in verse 56. They will surely face the consequences of their disobedience and denial, both in this world and in the Hereafter. In the Hereafter, they will be placed in Hell (Jahanam), and that is the worst place to return to.
text.58:
It is narrated by Ibn Abi Hatim from Muqatil Ibn Hayyan, that a man from the Ansar community, together with his wife Asma' binti Musyidah, prepared food for the Prophet PBUH. Then Asma' said, "O Messenger of Allah, how ugly is this. Indeed, entering the (room) of a wife and her husband while they are both in one covering, each of them, without permission," then this verse was revealed.

As we know, nowadays a house usually consists of several rooms, and each room is occupied by family members and other people in the house. There is a room for the head of the family and his wife, a room for the children, and a room for the servants, and so on. Usually, each family member can enter a room that is not theirs if there is a need and does not need to ask permission from the occupant of that room. However, Islam provides time limits for the freedom to enter other people's rooms. So slaves and children who have not reached puberty are not allowed to enter the parents' room or the room of a family member who is an adult and married at the specified times unless they ask permission first, such as by knocking on the door and so on. If there is an answer from inside, "Please come in," then they may enter. The specified times are: first, in the morning before the Fajr prayer; second, after Dhuhr; and third, after the Isha' prayer.

These times are called in this verse "aurat," because at those times people usually have not put on their clothes and their aurat has not been completely covered with clothing. In the morning before waking up for the Fajr prayer, people are usually still wearing sleeping clothes. The same is true during rest after Dhuhr and long rest after Isha'. During such rest times, husband and wife may be doing things that are not appropriate for others, servants, or children to see.

As for outside the three specified times, it would be very burdensome to require asking permission before entering those rooms, because servants and children should naturally move freely in the house because there is much to take care of and much that needs to be taken from those rooms. Servants usually enter rooms to clean them or to take something that is ordered by the master or mistress of the house, and the same is true for children.

Allah explains the etiquette in the household that must be obeyed and implemented. Experts in psychology, after conducting in-depth research, are of the opinion that underage children (before puberty) should not see things that are not yet appropriate for them to see because it will have a very large impact on their psychological development and may cause various kinds of mental illnesses. The wisdom of this etiquette is very great for the peace of the household, and indeed that is the case because this etiquette is commanded by Allah, the All-Knowing and All-Wise.
text.59: When children have reached puberty, they are treated like other adults; if they want to enter a room, they must ask permission first, not only at the specified times but at all times. Then Allah repeats His explanation that the guidance in this verse is His decree, which contains wisdom and benefits for harmony in the household. Indeed, He is All-Knowing of everything and All-Wise.
text.60: For elderly women who no longer have the desire for intercourse and no longer possess attractiveness, it is permitted to remove some of their clothing that is usually worn by women to cover the entire *aurat*, such as a housecoat (loose clothing that covers the entire body) and so on. However, they are not allowed to expose the *aurat* that is usually kept neatly covered, such as the chest, calves, thighs, and so on. If an elderly woman still wants to dress completely as usual, then that is better for her. In any case, a woman, even if she is old, is more honorable if she still pays attention to and prioritizes what is good for her to wear as a woman. Allah is All-Hearing and All-Knowing of all the actions of His servants and what is stored in their hearts.
text.61:
According to the customs of the Arabs since the Jahiliyah era, they did not feel any objection even if they were uninvited to the homes of relatives, and sometimes they brought along disabled family members to eat together. In this verse, the order of relatives has been arranged, starting from the closest, then the near ones, even including those who hold power or wealth, and close friends, because it is not uncommon for a friend to be left in our house without being invited or asking permission first. The order of the relatives is as follows:

1.  The closest to a person are his children and wife, but in this verse, children and wife are not mentioned because it is sufficient to mention "in your house" because it is common for a person to live with his children and wife. So, in the house of the children and wife, there is no need for permission or an invitation to eat first before eating. Likewise, if the child has established his own household, then his father may come to his child's house to eat without an invitation, because the child's house is actually his father's house as well, because the Prophet Muhammad saw once said: "You yourself and your wealth belong to your father." (Riwayat Ahmad dan Ashabus-Sunan)

2.  Father. A child does not need to ask permission from his father to eat first, because it is indeed the father's obligation to provide for his child. If the child has a family and lives separately from his father, he also does not need to ask permission to eat even though he no longer lives in his father's house.

3.  Mother. We already know how a mother's love is for her child. Even though her child is grown and has grandchildren, the mother's love remains the same as before. True is the saying, "a child's love is as long as a pole, and a mother's love is as long as the road." It is not a problem for her if her child eats in her house without an invitation, in fact, she will be very happy to see her child behaving as he did when he was still not an adult.

4.  Brother. The relationship between a person and his brother is a blood relationship that cannot be broken, even if there are disputes and quarrels. So, to foster a sense of brotherhood in each other's hearts, the relationship should not be limited by the formalities of ethics and protocols that apply to other people. How close the relationship between siblings is when someone comes to their sibling's house and eats together there.

5.  Sister, this is the same as eating at the brother's house.

6.  Father's brother (uncle).

7.  Father's sister (aunt).

8.  Mother's brother.

9.  Mother's sister.

10. The person who is given the power to take care of someone's property.

11. Close friend.

Thus, Allah states that no one, whether they have physical disabilities or not, should feel reluctant to eat in the homes of their relatives as long as their relatives truly do not feel reluctant about it, because kinship ties must be fostered and nurtured. Meanwhile, relationships with other people, such as with neighbors, both near and far, must be maintained as well as possible, especially relationships with relatives.

Even so, one should not do as one pleases towards one's relatives, especially if one's relatives are experiencing difficulties in their household and living in poverty, and then, because we have a kinship relationship, we all eat at their house in large numbers. A sense of mutual consideration and mutual help must be fostered as well as possible. If we see one of our relatives in need, then the relatives should work together to help and assist him. Then Allah explains again that it does not matter if a person eats together or alone.

It is narrated from Ibn 'Abbas, adh-ahhaq and Qatadah that this verse was revealed concerning Bani Lais bin Amr bin Kinanah, they felt very reluctant to eat alone. It once happened that one of them did not eat all day because there was no guest who would eat with him. As long as there was no one to accompany him to eat, he would not eat. Sometimes there were also those who had food available in front of them but they did not want to touch the food until the afternoon. There were also those who did not want to drink their camel's milk even though their camel had a lot of milk because there was no guest who would drink with him. Only when it was night and there were still no guests would he eat alone.

Hatim Ath-thÂ±i, a very famous generous person, said a verse of poetry to his wife:

If you cook food, then look for someone to eat it with me, because I will not eat that food alone.

So, to eliminate a habit that may seem good because it shows generosity in a person, but sometimes does not suit everyone's circumstances, Allah explains that a person may eat together and may eat alone.

One should not burden oneself with the habit of eating with guests, and then because there are no guests, he does not want to eat. Then Allah calls upon every believer that if he enters the house of one of his relatives, he should first greet the people of the house, namely the greeting that Allah has established, a greeting full of blessings and goodness, namely, "Assalamu'alaikum warahmatullahi wabarakatuh." Thus, the relatives in the house will be happy and joyful and receive him with an open heart.

Al-Hafiz, Abu Bakar al-Bazzar narrated that Anas said: The Messenger of Allah taught me five things. The Messenger of Allah said, "O Anas! Perform ablution perfectly, surely your life will increase, greet whoever you meet among my people, surely your goodness will increase greatly, when you enter your house, say greetings to your family; surely your house will be full of blessings, perform the duha prayer because the duha prayer is the prayer of the righteous people in the past. O Anas, love the children and respect the elders, surely you will be among my friends on the Day of Judgment."

Thus, Allah explains His verses as guidance for His servants, not only guidance regarding great things, but also guidance regarding small things. Hopefully, by practicing that guidance, we can think about how good and valuable that guidance is.
text.62:
In this verse, Allah explains that those who truly believe in Allah and His Messenger are those who, when they are with the Messenger of Allah discussing important matters concerning the affairs of the Muslims, do not want to leave the meeting before obtaining permission from the Messenger of Allah. Only after obtaining permission do they leave the meeting and give greetings to those present who are still with the Messenger of Allah.

From Abu Hurairah, from the Messenger of Allah, he said, "When one of you arrives at a gathering, let him give greetings. When he wants to sit, then let him sit. Then when he wants to leave, let him give greetings. The first is no more entitled than the last." (Narrated by Ahmad, Abu Daud, Ibn Hibban, and al-Hakim)

Those whose behavior is like that are the ones who truly believe in Allah and His Messenger. Then Allah commands the Messenger of Allah that if someone submits a request to leave a meeting with the Messenger of Allah, then the Messenger of Allah has the full right to accept or reject the request according to the circumstances of the person asking for permission and for what purpose he is leaving the meeting.

Umar bin al-Khaththab once asked the Messenger of Allah for permission to return to Medina to see his family during a journey with other companions towards Tabuk, so the Messenger of Allah gave Umar permission and said to him, "Return! You are not a hypocrite." The Messenger of Allah was also commanded, after giving permission to the person who requested it, to ask forgiveness from Allah for those who asked for permission. This is an indication that asking for permission, even though it is permissible to leave the meeting with the Messenger of Allah, the Messenger of Allah was ordered to ask forgiveness from Allah for that person. This shows that asking for permission and leaving the meeting is something that is not appropriate or reprehensible. It is as if the person prioritizes his own personal interests over the common interests in the presence of the Messenger of Allah. Thus, this is one of the manners of etiquette in associating with the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him). The Messenger of Allah is a Messenger who is honored by Allah, therefore it is not appropriate for a Muslim to treat him like other leaders who may have mistakes and errors.
text.63:
It is narrated by Abu Daud that there were among the hypocrites those who felt displeased listening to the sermon. Moreover, when they saw a Muslim asking permission to leave and being granted permission by the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), they would also leave with the person who had received permission, using him as cover. Then this verse was revealed.

Furthermore, as a sign of respect for the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), a Muslim is forbidden by Allah from calling the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) by his name alone, as is commonly done by the Arabs among themselves. Therefore, a Muslim is not allowed to call him "O Muhammad" or "O father of Qasim." And as a matter of etiquette and good manners towards the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), he should be addressed according to the position bestowed upon him by Allah, namely Rasul Allah (Messenger of Allah) or Nabi Allah (Prophet of Allah). Then Allah threatens those who leave a gathering with the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) in a secretive manner, fearing being seen. Such actions, even if unknown to the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), are known to Allah, and He knows the reasons that drive them to leave the gathering.

Allah warns such people who like to disobey commands, that they will be afflicted with misfortune or a painful punishment. Even if they are not afflicted with any misfortune in this world, in the Hereafter they will enter Hell, and that is the worst of outcomes.
text.64:
It is narrated by Abu Daud that there were among the hypocrites who felt displeased listening to the sermon. Moreover, when they saw a Muslim asking permission to leave and being granted permission by the Messenger of Allah, they would also leave with the person who had received permission, using him as a cover. Then this verse was revealed.

Then, as a sign of respect for the Messenger of Allah, a Muslim is forbidden by Allah from calling the Messenger of Allah by his name alone, as the Arabs usually did among themselves. So, a Muslim is not allowed to call him "O Muhammad" or "O father of Qasim." And as a matter of etiquette and good manners towards the Messenger of Allah, he should be addressed according to the position bestowed upon him by Allah, namely the Messenger of Allah or the Prophet of Allah. Then Allah threatens those who leave a gathering with the Prophet in a secretive manner, fearing being seen. Such actions, even if unknown to the Prophet, are known to Allah, and He knows the reasons that drive them to leave the gathering.

Allah warns such people who like to disobey commands, that they will suffer misfortune or a painful torment. Even if they are not afflicted with any misfortune in this world, in the Hereafter they will enter Hell, and that is the worst of all ends.

(64) Allah concludes Surah an-Nur after explaining that He is the Giver of light to the heavens and the earth and what is between them, and guides His servants through His messengers, and threatens those who disobey His commands by affirming that to Him belongs all that is in the heavens and the earth, and He knows the condition of all His servants and will reckon all their deeds and reward them accordingly. Evil deeds are rewarded in proportion to the evil committed, and good deeds are rewarded manifold, as mentioned in His word:

And you (O Muhammad) are not [engaged] in any matter or recite any Qur'an or perform any deed except that We are witness over you when you are involved in it. And not absent from your Lord is an atom's weight within the earth or within the heaven or [what is] smaller than that or greater, but it is in a clear register. (Yunus/10: 61)

Furthermore, in a hadith narrated by ath-Thabari, it is explained as follows:

It is narrated from 'Uqbah bin Amir, "I saw the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, while he was reciting the last verse of Surah an-Nur, he placed two of his fingers under the eyelids of his eyes and said: Allah is All-Seeing of everything." (Narrated by ath-Thabari and others)
